attributes.title: Meaning and prosociality
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
Independent variable - Manipulation Condition
Between-persons; Levels (1. Experimental; 2. Control)

The manipulation will involve participants being randomized to either an experimental or control condition reflective writing task. Participants in both conditions will be told that they are asked to perform a reflective writing exercise for 15 minutes in respect to a certain topic. Those in the experimental condition will be asked to read a paragraph that concerns the nature of meaning in life, and then be asked to write about the aspects of their life that they wish were more meaningful. Those in the control condition will be asked to write in detail about everything they have eaten over the past three days.

question2b.value:
Dependent variable - Prosocial behaviour

Once they have completed the manipulation task and manipulation check, participants will be told that they are welcome to leave, but can also stay back and help the experimenter with a side project that involves documenting changes in light pollution.
Prosociality will be measured by their decision to help the experimenter with the task, and if they offer - what sized package they offer to help with (larger package = more time consuming but more help to the project). Prosociality will be measured at two levels:
DV1) Offered to help (0 = help not offered; 1 = help offered)
DV2) Level of help offered (0 = help not offered; 1 = small package; 2 = medium package; 3 = large package)

question10b.value:
MANIPULATION
(see independent variable section above)

MEASURES/MATERIALS
Prosociality, Search for meaning, and various other personality and wellbeing-related questionnaires (see order of presentation).

Description of prosociality task (DV) - Documenting light pollution.
Once the participant has completed the Qualtrics survey (questionnaires and reflective writing task), they will be thanked for their participation and told that the study is over. However, at this point the experimenter will ask them if they wouldn't mind staying back a little longer to assist the experimenter in a side-project unrelated to the present study. The experimenter will tell them they are volunteering for a project involving documenting light pollution in the country and that they need help from other volunteers. The experimenter will say that help would involve seeing how many stars they can count in various photographs the experimenter has of the night sky taken around the city. If the participant offers to help, they will be told there are three packages they can choose to help with, a ~10-minute package, a ~15-20 minute package, and a ~20-25 minute package. They will be told the bigger package they choose the more help it is. Once they make their decision and take the relevant package, they will be told about the true nature of the paradigm, and debriefed by the experimenter.
Levels of DV:
DV1) Offered to help (0 = help not offered; 1 = help offered)
DV2) Level of help offered (0 = help not offered; 1 = small package; 2 = medium package; 3 = large package)


PROCEDURE
Order of presentation:
(Note: most of these scales are 'filler scales' to make up the 1-hour timeslot for the course-credit experiment. Some may be explored as potential moderators, however, this is not a planned or essential part of the per-registered hypotheses/analyses).
1. Demographic questions
2. UCLA Loneliness scale
3. Brief sensation seeking scale
4. Search for happiness scale
5. Life satisfaction scale
6. Valuing happiness scale
7. Honesty-humility scale
8. Prioritizing positivity scale
9. Boredom proneness scale
10. Big five inventory 2 scale
11. Random assignment to condition/reflective writing task
12. Reflective writing task (Experimental or control condition)
13. Meaning in life questionnaire (Search for meaning subscale - Manipulation check).
14. Prosociality task

Randomization and blinding
The experiment will be double blind. The participants will not be aware that the reflective writing task they have been administered either corresponds to an experimental or control condition (they will not know there are conditions at all). The experimenter will also be blind as to which condition the participant has been assigned to. The condition assignment will be randomized through the Qualtrics survey software and there will be no cues present to the experimenter regarding which condition/writing exercise the participant completed.

question4b.value: The recruited sample will be psychology undergraduates participating for course credit.

question5b.value: Data will be collected in the university laboratory by the experimenter (lead author of the manuscript). Recruited participants will be psychology undergraduates participating for partial course credit.

question6b.value:
Since this is the first experiment (to our knowledge) to study the relationship between meaning-seeking and prosociality, there is no prior effect size to use to determine our sample size. To be powered to detect a medium effect size (cohen's d = .50) for a two-tailed test with 0.8 power, we would require 64 participants per condition (128 total). 

It is possible that the true effect is smaller than .50. However, due to time constraints, data collection will likely only be able to run between March 2020 - May 2020, and so we are limited in the total number of participants that can be recruited. For this reason, we aim to recruit approximately 160 participants, and a maximum of 200 participants. This sample size should be adequately powered to detect a medium sized effect or just below a medium effect, and still be sufficiently powered after removing cases that do not meet the requirements for data analysis (see exclusion criteria).

question7b.value:
Data collection will likely be terminated in May 2020 due to a deadline. If this deadline is extended, then data collection may continue into August. 

Data collection will be terminated either when i) the study can no longer be run due to the deadline or ii) there is data for 200 participants with analyzable data (see exclusion criteria).

question8b.value:
Participants data will be excluded if they:
1) Fail either of the two attention checks built into the survey

2) Complete the Qualtrics survey in <1/3 of the median completion time.

3) If the content of their writing in the reflective writing task is not relevant to the specific task (e.g. in the experimental condition - if they do not write about aspects of their life they wish were more meaningful).

4) If it is made obvious they do not find the 'light pollution' prosociality task authentic (i.e. they make it clear that they see through the deception prior to making their decision to help or not)

4) They take too long with the questionnaires and reflective writing task parts of the study such that there is less than 15 minutes remaining in their scheduled participant timeslot, therefore not allowing enough time to potentially stay back and help the experimenter with the light pollution project (Prosociality DV).

question1a.value: Those assigned to the experimental condition will show significantly more helping behaviour (on prosocial behaviour task; dependent variable) compared to those assigned to the control condition.

question3a.value: Those randomized to the experimental condition will report a significantly higher search for meaning directly following the manipulation exercise compared to those randomized to the control condition.

question5a.value:
Our hypothesis follows from both theorising and previous evidence showing a consistent positive correlation between search for meaning and prosociality (Dakin, Laham & Bastian,  in prep; Studies 1-5). We theorise that this correlation exists because those searching for meaning are more motivated to perform prosocial acts due to the meaningfulness of these acts (see Van Tongeren et al., 2016; Klein, 2016). 

The purpose of this experiment is to try and provide causal evidence by showing that when you manipulate (increase) people's need to seek out meaning, it will increase their motivation to perform a prosocial action.

question1c.value:
IV - Condition (control = 1; experimental = 2)

DV - Prosociality
DV1) Offered to help (0 = help not offered; 1 = help offered)
DV2) Level of help offered (0 = help not offered; 1 = small package; 2 = medium package; 3 = large package)

question3c.value:
ANOVA 1
IV - Condition
DV - Offered to help (categorical)

ANOVA 2
IV - Condition
DV - Level of help offered (continuous)

question1c.value:
Further prediction: successful manipulation check (those assigned to experimental condition report significantly higher search for meaning than those assigned to control condition)

IV - Condition
DV - search for meaning (calculated by using average from 5-item from Meaning in Life Questionnaire search for meaning subscale; Steger et al., 2006).

question3c.value:
IV - Condition
DV - Search for meaning subscale

Data will be collected in the university laboratory by the experimenter (lead author of the manuscript). Recruited participants will be psychology undergraduates participating for partial course credit.

Since this is the first experiment (to our knowledge) to study the relationship between meaning-seeking and prosociality, there is no prior effect size to use to determine our sample size. To be powered to detect a medium effect size (cohen's d = .50) for a two-tailed test with 0.8 power, we would require 64 participants per condition (128 total). 

It is possible that the true effect is smaller than .50. However, due to time constraints, data collection will likely only be able to run between March 2020 - May 2020, and so we are limited in the total number of participants that can be recruited. For this reason, we aim to recruit approximately 160 participants, and a maximum of 200 participants. This sample size should be adequately powered to detect a medium sized effect or just below a medium effect, and still be sufficiently powered after removing cases that do not meet the requirements for data analysis (see exclusion criteria).

Data collection will likely be terminated in May 2020 due to a deadline. If this deadline is extended, then data collection may continue into August. 

Data collection will be terminated either when i) the study can no longer be run due to the deadline or ii) there is data for 200 participants with analyzable data (see exclusion criteria).

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Participants data will be excluded if they:
1) Fail either of the two attention checks built into the survey

2) Complete the Qualtrics survey in <1/3 of the median completion time.

3) If the content of their writing in the reflective writing task is not relevant to the specific task (e.g. in the experimental condition - if they do not write about aspects of their life they wish were more meaningful).

4) If it is made obvious they do not find the 'light pollution' prosociality task authentic (i.e. they make it clear that they see through the deception prior to making their decision to help or not)

4) They take too long with the questionnaires and reflective writing task parts of the study such that there is less than 15 minutes remaining in their scheduled participant timeslot, therefore not allowing enough time to potentially stay back and help the experimenter with the light pollution project (Prosociality DV).

q1.value: The Role of Structural (vs. Essentialist) Explanations for Status Hierarchies

q3.value: This study seeks to understand the role of explanation in children's reasoning about status-based social categories. Specifically, we intend to examine the effects of structural vs. essentialist explanations for status-hierarchies on (1) perceptions of low-status group members' social mobility, (2) attitudes toward low-status group members, (3) judgments of status hierarchies as fair, (4) perceptions of homogeneity both within and across status-based categories, and (5) perceptions flexibility for status-based categories. This project was motivated, in part, by previous work by Vasilyeva, Gopnik, and Lombrozo (2018) that illustrates children's capability to think in structural terms and differentiate between structural and internalist causes. Here, we intend to follow up on findings from an initial exploratory study of structural thinking that found structural explanations to increase perceptions of social mobility; in this follow-up, we will include additional measures of social-cognitive reasoning to further probe the down-stream consequences of structural thinking. Additionally, we will use pictures normed on relevant traits (e.g., attractiveness, friendliness, etc.) to eliminate possible confounds in our design.

q4.value:
Our hypotheses are as follows:

(1) Replicating our initial study, children in the structural explanation condition will perceive the low-status group to have more social mobility than children in the essentialist explanation condition.

(2) Children in the structural condition will report more positive attitudes toward low-status group members than children in the essentialist condition.

(3) Children in the structural condition will judge status hierarchies to be less fair than children in the essentialist condition.

(4) Children in the structural condition will perceive less homogeneity both within high- and low-status groups and between high- and low-status groups compared to children in the essentialist condition.

(5) Children in the structural condition will perceive the status-based categories to be more flexible (i.e., have less rigid boundaries) than children in the essentialist condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In this between-group paradigm, children will learn about two novel groups that differ in status. Critically, the explanation for this status difference will differ by condition: in the essentialist condition, children will learn that the status difference derives from something "deep inside" the group members and their families, while in the structural condition, children will learn that it is a result of "rules people made" a long time ago that still affect the group members and their families. After this manipulation, children will complete the following dependent measures:

(1) A measure of perceived social mobility, first within the same context in which the novel groups have been introduced, and then in a novel setting (i.e., "a different part of the world"). 

(2) A feelings thermometer measure to gauge children's attitudes toward the high-status and low-status target introduced at the beginning, as well as one new (gender-matched) member of each status group.

(3) A measure of how fair children perceive the described status hierarchy to be.

(4) A measure of children's perceptions of homogeneity both within and between the status-based categories.
 
(5) A measure of children's perceptions of how flexible each status-based category is (i.e., how rigid the category boundaries are).

q9.value: We will randomize the assignment of condition (structural explanation vs. essentialist explanation) across participants. To do so, we will use a random number generator to randomly assign participants to numbers that correspond to each condition, and subsequently administer only the assigned condition to each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will collect our data from two public elementary schools across New York City: one in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx. All participants will be recruited by lab-affiliated researchers who will disseminate consent forms to various classrooms in each school. Only children whose parents provide consent to participate will be eligible for this study. 

Further, our study will only include children who are in third, fourth, or fifth grade (likely between the ages of 8-11, with the possibility of 7-year-olds and 12-year-olds as well). All children must be able to understand English in order to be included in our sample. We plan to exclude all trials in which there is evidence of interference (e.g., from teachers or other children) and include partial data in our analyses. 

We plan to administer our study between March - May 2020. Children will not receive any monetary compensation for participation.

q13.value: We intend to collect data from 96 children in third through fifth grade (mostly between the ages of 8 and 11, with some potential 7- and 12-year-olds). Our sample will be evenly distributed between girls (N = 48) and boys (N = 48).

q14.value: This sample size is typical for studies of developmental social cognition and provides us to attain adequate power.

q15.value: We will terminate our data collection once a total of 96 children have been tested in the paradigm.

question.value: Our independent variable is the status explanation (structural vs. essentialist) to which children are assigned.

Our outcome variables are the following:

(1) Perceptions of social mobility, both in the familiar context and in a novel context -- measured on a scale of 1-5. (Across both contexts, 1 = perceptions that the low-status group can't achieve high status (really sure); 2 = perceptions that the low-status group can't achieve high status (sort of sure); 3 = perceptions that the low-status group can achieve high status (sort of sure); 4 = perceptions that the low-status group can achieve high status (really sure); 5 =  perceptions that the high-status group will achieve high status.)

(2) Feelings thermometer score for the high-status target, the low-status target, an unfamiliar member of the high-status group, and an unfamiliar member of the low-status group -- measured on a scale of 1 to 6. (Across all targets, 1 = "really not like"; 2 = "not like"; 3 = "sort of not like"; 4 = "sort of like"; 5 = "like"; and 6 = "really like".)

(3) Judgements of hierarchy fairness -- measured on a scale of 1 to 4. (1 = really not fair; 2 = sort of not fair; 3 = sort of fair; 4 = really fair.)

(4) Perceptions of within- and between-group homogeneity -- measured on a scale of 1 to 4. (Across both metrics, 1 = "a lot different"; 2 = "sort of different"; 3 = "sort of the same"; 4 = "a lot the same".) 
 
(5) Perceptions of category flexibility, both for the high- and low-status groups -- measured on a scale of 0 to 1. (Across both groups, 0 = "only possess category-consistent properties"; 1 = "sometimes possess category-inconsistent properties.) 

Additional predictor variables are (1) the age of participants, and (2) the status of the targets (for dependent measures #2, #4, and #5 -- see analysis plan for further details).

We plan to use linear regression to test our hypotheses. Specifically, we plan to test the following models in R using the lme4 package.

model1 <- social_mobility_same ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model2 <- social_mobility_diff ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model3 <- feelings_therm ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model4 <- fairness ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model5 <- homo_bw ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model6 <- homo_wi ~ condition*age_c, data = explain_high
model7 <- homo_wi ~ condition*age_c, data = explain_low
model8 <- homo_wi ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model9 <- flex ~ condition*group*age_c*type, data = explain

social_mobility_same = social mobility in familiar context score
social_mobility_diff = social mobility in different context score
feelings_therm = feelings thermometer score
fairness = fairness score
homo_bw = between-group homogeneity score
homo_wi = within-group homogeneity score
flex = category flexibility score

condition = status explanation condition (structural vs. essentialist)
age_c = child's mean-centered age
group = the status of the group (high or low)
type = the valence of the property type (positive or negative)

explain = dataframe with all responses
explain_high = dataframe of only high-status group
explain_low = dataframe of only low-status group

q21.value: We'll determine significance based on p-values produced from two-tailed statistical tests (p < .05).

q22.value: We do not intend to systematically exclude any data points.

q23.value: We plan to include all partial (i.e., incomplete) data in our analyses.

q24.value: As an exploratory analysis, we will examine the correlations among all of our dependent variables, as well as whether or not scores on one measure predict scores on any others.

registration_responses.q1: The Role of Structural (vs. Essentialist) Explanations for Status Hierarchies
registration_responses.q3: This study seeks to understand the role of explanation in children's reasoning about status-based social categories. Specifically, we intend to examine the effects of structural vs. essentialist explanations for status-hierarchies on (1) perceptions of low-status group members' social mobility, (2) attitudes toward low-status group members, (3) judgments of status hierarchies as fair, (4) perceptions of homogeneity both within and across status-based categories, and (5) perceptions flexibility for status-based categories. This project was motivated, in part, by previous work by Vasilyeva, Gopnik, and Lombrozo (2018) that illustrates children's capability to think in structural terms and differentiate between structural and internalist causes. Here, we intend to follow up on findings from an initial exploratory study of structural thinking that found structural explanations to increase perceptions of social mobility; in this follow-up, we will include additional measures of social-cognitive reasoning to further probe the down-stream consequences of structural thinking. Additionally, we will use pictures normed on relevant traits (e.g., attractiveness, friendliness, etc.) to eliminate possible confounds in our design.
registration_responses.q4:
Our hypotheses are as follows:

(1) Replicating our initial study, children in the structural explanation condition will perceive the low-status group to have more social mobility than children in the essentialist explanation condition.

(2) Children in the structural condition will report more positive attitudes toward low-status group members than children in the essentialist condition.

(3) Children in the structural condition will judge status hierarchies to be less fair than children in the essentialist condition.

(4) Children in the structural condition will perceive less homogeneity both within high- and low-status groups and between high- and low-status groups compared to children in the essentialist condition.

(5) Children in the structural condition will perceive the status-based categories to be more flexible (i.e., have less rigid boundaries) than children in the essentialist condition.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Our outcome variables are the following:

(1) Perceptions of social mobility, both in the familiar context and in a novel context -- measured on a scale of 1-5. (Across both contexts, 1 = perceptions that the low-status group can't achieve high status (really sure); 2 = perceptions that the low-status group can't achieve high status (sort of sure); 3 = perceptions that the low-status group can achieve high status (sort of sure); 4 = perceptions that the low-status group can achieve high status (really sure); 5 =  perceptions that the high-status group will achieve high status.)

(2) Feelings thermometer score for the high-status target, the low-status target, an unfamiliar member of the high-status group, and an unfamiliar member of the low-status group -- measured on a scale of 1 to 6. (Across all targets, 1 = "really not like"; 2 = "not like"; 3 = "sort of not like"; 4 = "sort of like"; 5 = "like"; and 6 = "really like".)

(3) Judgements of hierarchy fairness -- measured on a scale of 1 to 4. (1 = really not fair; 2 = sort of not fair; 3 = sort of fair; 4 = really fair.)

(4) Perceptions of within- and between-group homogeneity -- measured on a scale of 1 to 4. (Across both metrics, 1 = "a lot different"; 2 = "sort of different"; 3 = "sort of the same"; 4 = "a lot the same".) 
 
(5) Perceptions of category flexibility, both for the high- and low-status groups -- measured on a scale of 0 to 1. (Across both groups, 0 = "only possess category-consistent properties"; 1 = "sometimes possess category-inconsistent properties.) 

Additional predictor variables are (1) the age of participants, and (2) the status of the targets (for dependent measures #2, #4, and #5 -- see analysis plan for further details).
registration_responses.q19.question:
We plan to use linear regression to test our hypotheses. Specifically, we plan to test the following models in R using the lme4 package.

model1 <- social_mobility_same ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model2 <- social_mobility_diff ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model3 <- feelings_therm ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model4 <- fairness ~ condition*age_c, data = explain
model5 <- homo_bw ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model6 <- homo_wi ~ condition*age_c, data = explain_high
model7 <- homo_wi ~ condition*age_c, data = explain_low
model8 <- homo_wi ~ condition*group*age_c, data = explain
model9 <- flex ~ condition*group*age_c*type, data = explain

social_mobility_same = social mobility in familiar context score
social_mobility_diff = social mobility in different context score
feelings_therm = feelings thermometer score
fairness = fairness score
homo_bw = between-group homogeneity score
homo_wi = within-group homogeneity score
flex = category flexibility score

condition = status explanation condition (structural vs. essentialist)
age_c = child's mean-centered age
group = the status of the group (high or low)
type = the valence of the property type (positive or negative)

explain = dataframe with all responses
explain_high = dataframe of only high-status group
explain_low = dataframe of only low-status group

summary.value: This is a preregistration document for a secondary data analysis examining the influence of major local and national events on health, well-being, and productivity within a dataset of over 400 Lockheed Martin employees, consisting of on-body physiological wearables and environmental sensors, as well as subjective daily surveys. Data was acquired from participants across two study periods, of approximately two months each – in early 2018 (study 1) as well as late 2018 (study 2). This analysis project will estimate the effects of the California wildfires that occurred during study 2 (fall of 2018) on a variety of outcomes for these employees, as data was collected at a California Bay Area site. We will use an interrupted time series analysis (ITSA) to estimate the effects of the wildfires on our participants. The process outlined may be repeated for application to other event types present in the data. Data have been collected, but no ITSA have yet been conducted. This document lays out the procedures we will follow for estimating the models, including how we will make decisions regarding particular modeling strategies.

summary.value:
This is a preregistration document for a secondary data analysis of the effects of workplace proximity on well-being and productivity in Lockheed Martin office workers. This element of the project will estimate the influence of measures of organizational and spatial proximity on the behavior of networks representing similarity in emotional state and well-being between employees. Data were collected in two study periods, with each study spanning approximately two months at a Lockheed Martin facility. We will address two core questions:

(1)	How much does workplace proximity influence well-being and productivity? In other words, are participants who work together closely more similar to each other across these domains?
(2)	How much does workplace proximity influence reactions to significant events? In other words, if participants experience significant events or changes in their daily lives, do these changes have similar effects on people who work in closest proximity to them?

This document specifies how we will build the network representations of well-being and productivity similarities between employees and estimate the relationship between workplace proximity and the static structure and temporal dynamics of those networks.
